title.narrative: Skilling Youth for Employment in Agri-business

description.narrative: 8000 youth aged between 14 – 35 years in rural and urban locations; 65 Agribusinesses; 100 trainers from Agricultural institutions; 14 Agri-Institutions; 8 Secondary Schools.

AVSI Foundation was awarded a multi-year grant by the Embassy of the Kingdom of Netherlands in Uganda as part of the embassy’s Food Security Program to implement a 5-year project Skilling Youth for Employment in Agribusiness (SKY) with the aim of improving youth employability in the agribusiness subsector through skills development to respond to the demands of the local and international labour market. The implementation of the SKY project commenced in December 2015 in 30 districts in 4 regions of Uganda (Lake Victoria Crescent/Central, Western/South Western Uganda, Eastern Uganda/Elgon Area and Lango sub region). using a public-private partnership approach with the engagement of over 20 public and private educational institutions, 58 private agribusinesses and the Ministry of Education and sports under the Skilling Uganda framework. Ultimately the SKY project is part of the contribution of the Dutch people to the Uganda’s development agenda enshrined in the Vision 2040.

i. Agri-institutions’ capacity to skill strengthened ii. Pre and post-employment support to youth improved iii. Agribusiness Capacity to skill enhanced iv. Skilling Uganda’s Agriculture Sector Skills Council capacity boosted to support SKY project and skills development

participating-org.narrative: Bunyangabu Bee Keepers Cooperative Society Ltd
Manafwa Basen Rice Farmers Cooperative Ltd
Ministry of Education and Sports (Skilling Uganda Secretariat)
Nile Forestry Agro Inputs & Engineering Services
St. Benedictine Vocational Training & Production Centre

policy-marker.narrative: The main objective of SKY is to skill Ugandan youth for employment in agri-business

title.narrative: The AVSI SKY online results platform provides an up-to-date overview of the most important results, outputs and outcomes of the project
Curriculum documents produced with SKY support accredited by Uganda Government for use nationally for Skills Development

description.narrative: A deliverable taken off the 5-year plan of the Agriculture Sector Skills Council (ASSC) of Skilling Uganda, SKY committed to support the revision, updating, development, validation and approval of 10 Assessment and Training Packages (ATPs) for occupations in key agricultural value chains. The process was to be led by the National Curriculum Development Center (NCDC) in collaboration with the Directorate of Industrial Training (DIT) under the ownership of the ASSC.

title.narrative: Number of ATP documents finalized and approved for use

description.narrative: As planned, ASSC working with SKY and referencing the recommendations of the SKY contextual analysis report and the value chains selection report that was conducted in 2016 were able to profile various occupations in the agriculture sector for the purpose of developing or harmonizing ATPs to be used nationwide for end of training assessment and certification. DACUM experts affiliated to DIT were hired to lead the development and review process. A target of 10 was set but 11 ATPs were either developed or reviewed inorder to cater for all the skilling sites that had youth awaiting assessment having been trained along the value chains of Coffee, Mushroom, Plantain bananas, Poultry Production, Apiary, Diary Farming, Goats Rearing, Piggery, Tree Nursery Management, Fisheries, Cereal Farming and Horticulture. Experts in the various fields were engaged to develop/review the ATPs and industrial actors were then brought in to valid the ATPs with guidance and supervision of the National Curriculum Development Centre, MAAIF, DIT, ASSC and USDP.

comment.narrative: A need arose in Bukalasa Agricultural College where non-formal skilling in food processing was taking place to have the trainees assessed by DIT. This required an ATP that was subsequently developed for the prescribed purpose.

title.narrative: Agri-institutions (and secondary schools) strengthened to conduct quality agribusiness skills training

description.narrative: Agri-institutions and secondary schools are receiving support from SKY to improve the practical aspects of the training to their students and include labour market-responsive modules such as soft skills and financial management into their curriculum. SKY's package include both software and hardware support. A unique dimension of the support is the development of business models for the agri-institutions and schools to engage in agribusiness to generate their own income.

title.narrative: Cumulative number of agri-institutions and schools that receive the capacity improvement package from SKY project

description.narrative: Number of institutions classified as strengthened divided by the total number of institutions engaged Functional infrastructure established by SKY and other engagements facilitated (exposure visits, linkages etc)

comment.narrative: The 7 secondary schools were maintained for support in 2018 and a target to reach 14 agri-institutions was retained

As the implementation commenced in 2018, it was agreed that a secondary school would be engaged in the Lango area to extend the mindset change intervention to the area, this brought the number of secondary schools engaged to 8. An additional agri-institution was added to the 14 to cater for a need that arose in Western Uganda where graduates of Ibanda Vocational institute who would come to IBO mixed farm exhibit huge gaps in hands on abilities due to poor training at the institute. SKY made the decision to engage Ibanda VTI and accord it all the capacity support other VTIs received.

In the first year of the project it was envisaged that there would be a slow start to actual implementation so a small number of schools and agri-institutions were targeted. The target number was achieved and surpassed by one.
St. Paul's College Mbale was dropped at the end of 2018 because the school became disinterested in the collaboration with SKY

The target number of agri-institutions was not achieved by -1 in 2017 because one bureaucratic red-tapes in one of the centers that dragged the process till the end of the year. The number of secondary schools in the East (2 were targeted) was surpassed by 1 because in the Eastern Region 3 schools were engaged in order to cover each of the 3 sub-regions of Busoga, Bukedi and Bugisu with a center of excellence as requested at a stakeholder meeting

title.narrative: Agribusinesses capacitated to offer quality skill training

description.narrative: One of the main outcomes of SKY is to build the capacity of the agribusinesses engaged to be able to offer high standards skills development services. The range of capacity improvement support include establishment of production units for practical sessions, training of instructors in appropriate and updated pedagogical methods, development of strategic and business plans and gaining accreditation from the Ministry of Education as Assessment Centers.

title.narrative: Number of agri-businesses capacitated to skill under SKY since the inception of the project

dimension.name: Agribusinesses established by Agripreneurs with SKY support

comment.narrative: There were agribusinesses that had been assessed at the contexual survey stage of the SKY project and had been put in a packing lot, to be engaged as the need for more enrollment arose. It was envisioned that by the 3rd year of the project, early riser graduates who become agripreneurs would be eligible for consideration to be engaged as skilling partners.

Many of the youth enrolled opted for a small range of occupations in value chains that SKY already had an adequate number of partners engaged and capacitated to skill in, this limited the number of new agribusinesses to bring on board in 2018. For occupations where the number of youth interested was less than 20, a deliberate decision was made to engage the graduate agripreneurs to do the skilling as a way of getting them on their feet as skills development actors and to testing the strength of the peer-peer skilling approach using our own graduates.

title.narrative: Employed SKY graduate youth 18-35 years amassed cumulative income of €3.6 million

description.narrative: The EKN target for the project period is €3,600,000 (UGX15,480,000,000/=)

title.narrative: Total income earned by all the youth who have been skilled by the SKY project

comment.narrative: In the second year of employment, the self-employed youth are expected to have stabilized and thus more income registered

Current projections for income for the reference period is based on the MTR findings that put 1,001 self-employed youth earning UGX650,000 (€151) per month and 936 wage employed youth earning average net income of UGX212,000 (€49) per month. This gives a total of 1,937 youth currently employed earning an average of UGX 440,500 (€102) for an average people of 12 months. This put the cumulate earnings of SKY youth at an estimate of €2,370,888 (UGX10,194,818,400/=), 32% above the €1.8m target for 2018.
The self-employed youth have struggled, as expected in the first year in employment due to the need for incubation before large scale productive activities are embarked on
In 2019, the target was for the employed youth to earn an additional €1,000,000. Adding to the 2018 cumulative target of €1800000, the 2019 target total will be €2800000

title.narrative: Employed SKY-trained youth 18-35 years earned at least €70/month

description.narrative: The target of the project is that at the end of the project period each of the skilled and employed youth should be earning at least €70.00/month, an amount that places them 2 levels above the poverty level and enables them to meet their basic needs especially their food security.

title.narrative: Average income generated by both self and wage employed youth that were trained in the SKY project (EUR/month)

comment.narrative: Wage employed youth continue to earn less because their pay is determined by the agribusinesses that employ them at is taken from profits. Because there is no minimum wage policy in Uganda, many agribusinesses are still paying low.

title.narrative: Youth 18-35 years enrolled to be skilled for immediate employment

description.narrative: The target of the project was to hit the enrollment target of 8,000 beneficiaries (6,000 youth 18-35 to be skilled for employment and 2,000 youth for mindset change in secondary school). With a projected dropout rate of about 5%, the project covered this by raising the enrollment level to 8,400 – 8,800 beneficiaries which in the event of the occurrence of predicted dropout rate the final beneficiary count will still meet the desired 8,000 number.

title.narrative: Number of youth enrolled by agribusinesses and agri-institutions to be trained for immediate employment

comment.narrative: Much as there was no planned enrollment for 2019, some Agri-institutions had a balance on enrollment and admitted them in 2019, thus the 583

title.narrative: Skilled youth are employed by agribusinesses

description.narrative: This is the number of youth who have been skilled and are wage-employed in agribusiness

title.narrative: Youth trained and retained as employees of the agribusiness that skilled them or other agribusinesses
Skilled youth assessed for employability by Directorate of Industrial Training

description.narrative: This is the total cumulative number of youth who have completed their skilling cycle and have undergone assessment for 1 occupational level by the Directorate of Industrial Training (DIT) of the Uganda Ministry of Education and Sports

title.narrative: Number of youth assessed by DIT under SKY since the inception of the project

description.narrative: Once the trainee youth have completed all the lined up modules and have done sufficient hands on practicals, the skilling center applies to the DIT for consideration of Assessment. The DIT then proposes an assessment slot and the center fills a form for each youth accompanied by UGX70,000/= as assessment fee per youth. DIT then choose the module(s) on which the youth will be assessed and the center prepares all the materials required for the activity.

comment.narrative: There is significant variance between the target and the actual number of assessed youth because many of the skilling centers have taken long to acquire assessment center numbers so assessment cannot be conducted before they are accredited and DIT do not have sufficient manpower to cover all sites in a timely manner

title.narrative: In-school youth 14-17 years enrolled and skilled for mindset change

description.narrative: Using the Sports for Agribusiness model, youth in 8 secondary schools (Gayaza High School, Luigi Giussani High School, Maryhill High School, Nyakasura School, Iganga Secondary School, Tororo Girls School, St. Paul's College Mbale and Adwari SSS) underwent skills training in the fields of agronomy, entrepreneurship, life-skills and basketball. Basketball was used as a vehicle to bring the youth together and bring out the competitiveness in them to set the stage to deliver the other components. A1 Challenge Ladies Basketball Club was engaged to run the life-skills and basketball sessions. AVSI handled the agronomy and entrepreneurship components

title.narrative: Total number of youth 14-17 years in secondary schools who attended at least 70% of all planned mindset change activities

comment.narrative: The activity was deliberately positioned to target more girls than boys as the girl child needs more empowerment to make it in the complex Ugandan society of today. So not a coincidence that 4 of the targeted schools are girls schools and the other 4 are mixed. There is no purely boys' schools selected

The interest of the youth to join the Sports for Agribusiness intervention has been very high. For this reason the project and the schools have agreed to allow more youth join the club thus almost doubling the targeted number.

title.narrative: Youth successfully completed skills training

description.narrative: Youth 18-35 years who have successfully completed skills training enrolled for

title.narrative: number of youth 18-35 years who successfully complete their skilling programme

comment.narrative: The total number enrolled was 7148 youth, over 1000 beyond the target of 6000. with a completion rate of 87% the final number at the end of 2018 was above the 100% mark.
The plan is to have all enrolled youth graduated by end of 2018, so none expected for 2019
There were 583 enrollments by Agri-Institutions out of which 489 completed the skilling in 2019

title.narrative: Youth graduates are self-employed agripreneurs

description.narrative: Youth who receive incentives (startup kits) divided by total number of youth who start their own business (self-employed)

title.narrative: # of youths owned agribusinesses that receive incentives

description.narrative: Number of youth self-employed after training under SKY since the inception of the project

comment.narrative: So far, 6,273 (4,031 males and 2,242 females) youth (18-35 years) have completed their skills training and 2,377 have been assessed and 99.7% certified by the Directorate of Industrial Training (DIT). Of these, 1,001 (631 males and 370 females) and 936 (are now self-employed and waged employed respectively. The self-employed youth are earning more than the wage-employed youth with average monthly income of €151 and €49 respectively, falling on either ends of the project target of €70 per employed youth per month. This outcome gives validation to the skilling approach that it improves employability of the youth and indicate a favorable projection that the employed youth will live above the poverty line once their income stabilizes and improves.
The start-up kits that was handed to the youth in the beginning of 2019 enabled the youth to set up agripreneurships that got them into self-employment. Most of them in the Horticulture value chain
